newsitem.title: CROATIA: Croatian lending rate eases back to 7.7 pct.
newsitem.headline: Croatian lending rate eases back to 7.7 pct.

text.p: The weighted price of kuna loans eased back to 7.7 percent on Thursday from 8.6 percent despite stronger demand on Croatia's money market.
Main lending rates remained unchanged: 8.0 percent for interbank placements, save for one new smaller 15-30 day loan made at 11 percent.
Insurers rolled over previous funds at seven percent.
Total settlements were more than doubled at 19.6 million kuna, of which 10 million were fresh interbank borrowing. Supply shrank to 90 million kuna.
Wednesday's overnight trade totalled a meagre 0.6 million kuna as only one bank had a shortfall and borrowed money to square its position.
The central bank calculated the kuna firmer at 5.3639 versus 5.3797 to the dollar and slightly weaker at 3.5546 versus 3.5533 to the German mark. -- Kolumbina Bencevic, Zagreb Newsroom, 385-1-4557075
